content.html_value:
Among the many talks I had with genealogist Gilber Rubim Rangel, author of various historical books (Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário de Genealogia ; Rangel, Gilber Rubim, Dicionário de Genealogia, Instagram ; Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário Histórico-Geográfico do Estado do Espírito Santo), some pages of the books are accessible on the Archive website (Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário de Genealogia ; Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário Histórico), one particularly inspired the creation of this section. We discussed the different myths that have been, and still are, created to shape our ancestors into the characters we desire (Rangel, Gilber Rubim, , Dicionário de Genealogia, pp. 262 - 264).

Genealogy is not the only area of history where myths and beliefs are created; many historical events have been taught in their mythological versions, as recent research shows. To help readers better understand these beliefs and myths, we have cataloged brief descriptions below. By clicking on the links, you will be directed to pages where you can expand your knowledge about them and discover the facts behind these myths.

The myths can be updated at any time based on new research.

value.name: Relationship between the Banu Qasi and the Arabs
value.desc: Various studies have suggested that some members of the Banu Qasi might be descendants of Musa ibn Nusair and the prophet Muhammad. However, there is no known documentation to support these claims (Medieval Lands, , Moorish Spain). Often, hypotheses are taught as facts to support desired connections.

value.name: Did the Indigenous peoples of the Americas (Abya Yala) come from the Middle East 4,000 years ago?
value.desc: Genetic data, rock paintings, and construction datings show that this belief has no foundation. It was likely derived from a mistaken interpretation of some text.

value.name: When we find an altar or stela with people shown in sequence, does that mean they represent consecutive generations?
value.desc: Not necessarily. The Altar Q of Copán, in Honduras, for example, may include brothers among the 16 ajawob (kings) represented.

value.name: Are monogamous families the only type of family?
value.desc: As Morgan pointed out, there are different types of families, with the monogamous one being only one among them (Engels, Frederick, , pp. 712 - 719). This is a common misunderstanding, resulting from mistaken literary interpretations or from living exclusively within a single type of social group. In extreme cases, this misconception can lead to inappropriate classifications, such as those made by the Jesuits (Schmitz, P. I., & Rogge, J. H., , pp. 259).

value.name: Did the first Incas emerge from Lake Titicaca?
value.desc: Multicellular species do not arise or get created in a simple way. On a planet billions of years old, like Earth (Allegre, C. J., Manhes, G., & Göpel, C., ), the evolution of species occurred gradually, through specific changes that allowed the emergence of new species via a process called speciation (Speciation, National Geographic)

value.name: Was there a birth of a Jesus Christ among the Incas?
value.desc:
In his work, Felipe Guaman Poma de Ayala makes several mentions of Jesus Christ; in one of them, he presents him as the son of a Sapa Inca, Sinchi Roca, and his wife (Poma de Ayala, Felipe Guaman, , pp. 123). Since other texts report that Jesus Christ lived thousands of years earlier (Mateus, Cap. 1:6-16), this represents an anachronism.

On the other hand, cultural exchange has always occurred in human history, leading to the depiction of saviors with common characteristics (Graves, K., ):

Livro 1: Livro de Kersey Graves.

value.name: Is it impossible to find enslaved ancestors?
value.desc: Although enslaved people were marginalized and many documents were destroyed by government order (Lacombe, Américo Jacobina, , pp. 114), it is still possible to trace the lineages of enslaved individuals through religious records and inventories.

value.name: Were the descendants of Bráz Esteves and Leonor Leme nobles?
value.desc: To answer this question, we must consider that so-called nobles had to belong to an 'agnatic patrilineal' lineage (SOTTOMAYOR-PIZARRO, J. A. de., ). Since Bráz Esteves and Leonor Leme changed the name of their own father to conceal their maternal lineage, they could not be considered nobles, neither by lineage nor by their actions.

value.name: Did Pedro Leme have three marriages?
value.desc: Almost a century after Leonor Leme altered her maternal lineage of the Leme family, she became a victim of the same action by a descendant, who made her husband into her uncle in order to 'remove her from the way'.

value.name: In the past, the firstborn children were named after their parents
value.desc: This argument is often used to create connections and extend genealogical trees, but it faces the problem that this practice was not always followed. For example, the genealogy of the Kings of León shows instances where this tradition was not maintained.

value.name: Are European kings descendants of the Visigoths?
value.desc: There is an attempt to create a continuous lineage between kings of different empires and civilizations. However, when it comes to the Visigoths, they should be considered in isolation. It is important to explicitly state that connections to them are largely hypothetical.

value.name: Who claimed that indigenous peoples are inherently different?
value.desc: I've noticed a tendency among some individuals to marginalize others or perceive themselves as superior based on personal preferences or the echo chambers they inhabit. But is there any factual basis for this notion of superiority? Having made similar errors myself, whether it was celebrating a sports victory or receiving misguided teachings, I've included research here that aims to address this question from a technical standpoint, both concerning indigenous peoples and the broader population.

value.name: Who truly discovered America (Abya Yala)?
value.desc: While this question may seem straightforward and readily answered in history books, it's essential to recognize the limitations of solely adhering to one worldview.

value.name: Who said indigenous peoples never had mathematical tools?
value.desc: Among the misconceptions surrounding indigenous communities is the claim that they lacked arithmetic instruments. However, both ancient chronicles and recent studies demonstrate that they indeed developed their own techniques for arithmetic calculations.

value.name: Do races exist among humans?
value.desc: Some comparisons can be made in a simple way with indisputable results—for example, when comparing circles () with squares (), we can easily determine whether they are equal or not. In the case of so-called races, however, it is not enough to look at skin color or hair type. The issue must be examined at an internal level, and through genetics we find that we are all the same specie.

value.name: Was there a Flood?
value.desc: There is much confusion about the relationship between science and beliefs. In this text, we aim to show that science does not seek to destroy beliefs; rather, it helps us better understand what ancient texts convey.
It is tempting to answer this question right away, but it is always important to first ask what exactly we are adding before giving the answer.

value.name: Are addition and multiplication independent operations?
value.desc: Often, the way mathematics is taught leads to a mistaken understanding of multiplication. In reality, multiplication can be understood as the repeated addition of the same quantity.

value.name: Did the Indigenous peoples lack the knowledge and technology to build pyramids?
value.desc: The Indigenous civilizations of the Americas (Abya Yala) had all the knowledge necessary to construct monumental buildings on the continent. This was mainly due to careful observation of nature. Regarding the mathematical tools they used, they also left direct and indirect evidence that they mastered them.
